name: solanum-americanum
distribution:
and the United States except for the State of Hawaii;
Introduced: Belgium
wildlife-value: The flowers attract insects, bumblebees, and flies. The black berries are eaten by some birds including wild turkeys, catbirds, meadowlarks, and pheasants.
edibility: The plant is toxic, particularly the leaves and berries.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: The fruits are initially clusters of green berries with white flecks. They become shiny black or purplish-black berries when ripened. Each berry is round and less than 0.25 inches in diameter. Each berry contains 50- 100 tiny light tan-colored seeds. The berries are toxic to livestock.
flower-description: The flowers occur umbellate cymes or clusters. Each umbel has 3 to 10 flowers. Each bloom is star-shaped, white, five-petaled which curves backward, and has bright yellow stamens in the center of the flower.
leaf-description: The leaves are up to 1.5 to 3 inches long, up to 2 inches wide, green to dark green, simple, alternate, ovate or lanceolate, smooth with wavy or slightly toothed margins. The undersides of the leaves are slightly hairy. The leaves are toxic to livestock.
stem-description: The stem is erect, angular, and many-branched. The stem surface may be smooth or slightly hairy, but it is not prickly.
poison-symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, drowsiness, abdominal pain, diarrhea, weakness, respiratory depression; convulsions, hallucinations; may be fatal.
uses: American nightshade is used as a medicine in some parts of the world. The leaves are used to make poultices to treat skin inflammations or conjunctivitis.
